body: Yes, it's better if you can orelse installing the cluster this change where we can show that it's not taking time.
I have created a new PR to clean up commit logs. => https://github.com/apache/ambari/pull/3361

Test Verification with Patch:

Thanks for providing the PR.

Slf4j 2.0.0 requires JDK8. Realistically i don't think Ambari should continue support JDK7 but I couldn't find where the project states the version of JDK being supported.
How do we ensure this is all that's needed for mysql8? I see there are a number of sql files.
Thanks @jojochuang for the info. I can see only two MYSQL sql script in the resource. Can you please tell me the other Mysql sql script path? so that also I will test once.

Yes, almost all the component uses jdk8 only and I have verified the changes on jdk8. The java validation is added in the server configuration class. We can create separate jira to add maven enforcer for java version.

Thanks. I just found out wiki states 2.7.x must run with JDK8.
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AMBARI/Ambari+Development

The above triggered build went well, we can wait for [the latest one](https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Ambari/job/Ambari-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/view/change-requests/job/PR-3357/4/). If it's good, I think this is good to go.

> Could you explain why get file status again resolved the issue?

Refer to https://github.com/apache/bigtop/pull/1000#issuecomment-1248846681.

In this scenario, when I use HdfsResource upload a file, the logic is:
1. Obtain the file status: owner=ambari-qa
2. If the files are inconsistent, upload the file again. In this case, the file permission is owner= HDFS
3. Grant permissions. The assigned permissions are consistent with the file status permissions, and file permissions are not updated

Because the file status first obtained was outdated, then `_set_owner` function will not take effect. This is not reasonable.

And the updated logic is:
1. Obtain the file status: owner=ambari-qa
2. If the files are inconsistent, upload the file again. In this case, the file permission is owner= HDFS
3. Obtain the file status again, and the file permission is owner= HDFS
4. Assign permissions. If the assigned permissions are inconsistent with the file status permissions, update the file permissions

Of course, this may be redundant when creating the file for the first ti.me, but it requires refactoring the code that created the file.

## Successfully Installed Services

Please go through following committer guideliness, there are some more.

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AMBARI/How+to+Commit

A committer must sign off on a patch. It is very helpful if the community also reviews the patch, but in the end a committer must take responsibility for the correctness of the patch. If the patch is simple enough and the committer feels confident in the review, a single +1 from a committer is sufficient to commit the patch. (Remember committers cannot review their own patch. If a committer submits a patch, they should make sure that another committer reviews it.)

that doesn't mean, we should merge to ambari directly.

No worries, I was going to test and provide the approval anyways. @kevinw66 also asked to forward-port an HDFS related change that I committed ~3 yr back to branch-2.7 but it was not merged to trunk yet. I will create forward-port PR soon.

Otherwise this PR seems good. We can wait next time onwards. Thanks everyone

With this PR, now it also means that from trunk (3.0.0+) onwards, we no longer need to depend on HDP (or replacement) stack and maybe that's for good, but HDP (or replacement) stack is still required for immediate 2.7.7 release. We will have to maintain common changes accordingly b/ trunk and branch-2.x until 2.x releases are EOL'ed.

Sorry, the commit is confused, I will resubmit.

Related by https://github.com/apache/bigtop/pull/1000#issuecomment-1247877540

To reproduce the problem:
1. Deploy Hdfs, Yarn, Mapreduce, zookeeper Ambari UI first.
2. Execute `useradd tez` on `ambari-server`, `ambari-agent-01`, `ambari-agent-02`.
3. Execute Mapreduce service check again.

This lead to the /etc/passwd(source file MapReduce checked) file size changed, and then cause MapReduce Service Check Failed.

@kevinw66
